Amazon.reviewText: Solid Joh Great pay benefits and steady overtime. Fast paced and always new challenges. Biggest problem is poor management not holding their own weight.

What is the best part of working at the company?
I enjoyed the fast paced environment and there was a very focused process with constant updates to safety and processes that made my job safer and easier. The benefit package was amazing as well as time off paid and unpaid and the accumulated vacation time earned. There is an open line of communication between management and staff

What is the most stressful part about working at the company?
Keeping up with the changes in departments other than your normal department just in case you are moved to another department to assist.

What is the work environment and culture like at the company?
I enjoyed the environment and was able to meet a wide diverse group of people from many different places and circumstances. I just recommend staying neutral in employee disagreement unless you are witness to an injustice because if not you could find yourself entangled in drama at work.

What is a typical day like for you at the company?
My day was fast paced. I was well trained in my position and was able to move between departments so I never got bored
talking with folks and getting a good workout. also they sometimes play favorites and stuff here but seems that anywhere these days. The workplace culture is great just

Good place to work..some nice people there..alot of people you couldn't understand & some very mean ones...but they would get the mean out if they heard bout them...insurance was great..loved the packing job

I recently interviewed with Amazon, and it was an eye-opening experience. The process was well-organized and began with a straightforward "Tell me about yourself" prompt, which set a comfortable tone. The interviewers were professional and focused, showing genuine interest in understanding why I was drawn to the position. They delved into my motivations, and it was clear they valued candidates who align with Amazon's mission and long-term vision. One of the more challenging aspects was discussing how to handle conflicts with colleagues, which highlighted the company's emphasis on teamwork and effective communication. The entire experience was rigorous yet fair, reflecting Amazon's high standards and commitment to hiring candidates who can thrive in a collaborative and dynamic environment.
I love working for the company and the flexibility they have mornings nights and flex shift part time and full full time also tuition reimbursement also is great
Too long for growth, and the management is unprofessional and rude. Too many chiefs, not enough indians. Long hours, Your off days are usually all together. Mandatory extra days during Peak season.

I have worked here for almost 3 years and I have done a wide array of work activities. Each area is easy in its own way, it is a very repetitive job and rates are enforced, at least it looks like they are. Many people should have been fired long ago but due to the fact that they are not enforced they are still there doing the same old mistakes without any punishment.

Amazon provides opportunities to grow but lacks leadership and communication. Employees are offered opportunities to join projects and have training but stepping up to level 3 and above internally is really difficult
Good for newbies, management listens to their employees as long as its doable. How difficult the work is depends on the department, con: no incentives

For the most part, the experience working here is what you make out of it - the management or leaders keep changing every year (or 6 months) and everyone is busy growing themselves; so it all comes down to how driven are you for your own growth/promo/learnings etc. 
The average tenure at the company is less than 2 years mostly because of the toxicity/politics within orgs mostly arising due to the “PIP” culture leading to poor work life balance.
Good for begginers to start their carieer wirh high quality colligues and most nice managers to imprpve your skills. They respect your ideas and give you fredeem

Enjoyed the team and the work. Got to work on interesting projects. The work requires lots of bias for action and you have to internalise all the LPs in order to be effective at your job. No one is going to hold your hand and tell you exactly what to do. You have to figure put a lot of things by yourself

Not a career job, just simply an easy job to get when your between carreer jobs and need to pay the bills. Management is young, and have little to no training. Simply put, ran by kids fresh out of college, given a title and a fat salary, all to stand around and do nothing all day, except stare at a laptop. You are worked like a dog most days and are expected to meet ridiculous hourly rates, and the pay does not match the amount of labor you put in by far.
A lot of new things to do everyday. I enjoyed myself working there for 4 years. Things changed but overall a great experience. Wishing the best for everyone

I’ve worked at Amazon as a delivery driver multiple times. The job itself is not hard, it’s just a lot of work and physically demanding. A workout everyday. It’s a good work/life balance, seems like management cares…BUT for the work the pay definitely can be better

Good first job but a little disorganized, mostly due to frequent changes in management. Expect to wear many hats, and this is what makes the job difficult. Management could care less who does what. Someone will have to step up. It becomes like a "mind game" between the employees in regards to who will do more work. Management don't care what employees say or do as long as the job gets done.
Varied tasks and autonomy,  learned a ton, good pay and benefits, not an employee centric culture. Incompetence promoted to get them out of operations

good company, however there are some micromanagers
you can learn alot, and it has opportunities to grow
very fast paced, and sometimes it gets overwhelming

It can be harder for some and easier for others depending on your role. Money, benefits, and insurance are great. Advancement is possible for anyone degree or not. Everyone's experience is different with such a large company/locations but overall was a great experience/learning time for me.
good job bad management. Not a job for lazy people. Can be tiring and challenging. both mentally and physically. Worst part about it is the management for sure
